item.title: Day5: Struga-Bitola
item.dc:creator: sivevsky
item.description:
There is nothing much to say about this day. The last kilometers  were exhausting but nothing gives you more energy as the realization that  you will reach your home soon.This was the final destination of the 500 km trip. As a first trip, it was challenging for   me and i learned a lot from it. …

Day5: Struga-Bitola Read More »
item.content:encoded:
There is nothing much to say about this day. The last kilometers  were exhausting but nothing gives you more energy as the realization that  you will reach your home soon.
This was the final destination of the 500 km trip. As a first trip, it was challenging for   me and i learned a lot from it. At the same time it gave me courage to go on and repeat the process with a longer trip somewhere in Europe. And it was actually like i  planned. The next year, i organized my second big trip from Vienna to Split.

item.title: Day4: Tirana-Struga
item.dc:creator: sivevsky
item.description:
The road from Tirana direction Elbasan was quiet and peaceful. My main concern was if i  would be able to avoid the newly build motorway which was connecting both cities. I knew that the local  road will end soon and i will have to  face the motorway challenge. I was lucky enough to make a …

Day4: Tirana-Struga Read More »
item.content:encoded:
The road from Tirana direction Elbasan was quiet and peaceful. My main concern was if i  would be able to avoid the newly build motorway which was connecting both cities. I knew that the local  road will end soon and i will have to  face the motorway challenge. I was lucky enough to make a coffee brake just on the crossroad where the the local road joined the highway. I asked the owners of the coffee shop   and they told me  this is the only way to Elbasan. I got scared to death especially when i moved a few meters and saw the motorway full of long tunnels. There is no way i would go there with the bicycle. That is  for sure a dead penalty. I rode a few km back in despair what to do. Should i not find another solution, i would have to go back in Tirana and get a bus to Struga. But  luck was my partner again. I asked some passing people if there is an old road to Elbasan and they informed that there is a forgotten mountain road that circles around and goes to Elbasan. That was all i wanted to hear!
That road was the most beautiful biking road that i could have imagined. It was an abandoned car road but  in perfect condition and there was no single car passing by! At some point i got scared if something happens to me here, nobody will ever find me.
The road was going around the mountain for 25 km before heading down to the industrial part of Elbasan. Once arrived in Elbasan i was welcomed with a huge sight of an abandoned metallurgical complex from the communist era. Once upon a  time the whole city lived from this place. Now it is a shelter for the devils.

As a result of this complex which had devastating effects on the environment, Elbasan is one of the most polluted cities in the world. In general, the city is poor with lots of  disintegrating communist buildings .It is clear  that the Albanian government has abandoned the east part of the country.
I didn’t want to stay long in this place and  my plan was to give maximum effort so i can cross the border until the evening. After all, those huge mountains which i observed from the bus when i was going to Dubrovnik  now had to be faced and conquered.
I followed the local road which was narrow  but luckily without too much traffic. I gave full gas and although tired from the long day i was determined to climb the mountain and reach the border. I made one or two small breaks in the mountain villages.
The plan was successful and  i reached the city of Struga around eight  pm. I found a shelter in a local house and i declared  to myself that my bike trip was successful .
I had only 100 km left ,but those were in home territory and as such i didn’t consider them as a challenge.

item.title: Day3: Skadar-Tirana
item.dc:creator: sivevsky
item.description:
The  ride was long but i was lucky to ride all the time behind Markus and with that i had the wind as my friend. For anyone new in biking: it is  an enormous difference to ride at the the top of the row or to be hidden in the back. After a few breaks …

Day3: Skadar-Tirana Read More »
item.content:encoded:
The  ride was long but i was lucky to ride all the time behind Markus and with that i had the wind as my friend. For anyone new in biking: it is  an enormous difference to ride at the the top of the row or to be hidden in the back. After a few breaks for coffee and beer, we entered the suburbs of Tirana which were dirty and overcrowded with cars. This picture changed when we entered the city center: in front of me was a European busy city, full of palm trees. We in Macedonia have totally different picture about Tirana and always use it in negative connotation.
Markus is an artistic soul and he found another good hotel in the city center form where we were able to discover the city by day and night.
The next morning our ways separated since i continued to direction Elbasan and Markus to direction South Albania and Greece. Before that,  i was honored to be a part of his documentary named “From Berlin to Athens“. For this purpose i gave a short interview in which i explained my reasons why i choose to make this trip.
I took the road to Elbasan in the late afternoon and after struggling to get out of Tirana, i finally found a local road to take me in the desired direction.

item.title: Day2: Budva-Skadar
item.dc:creator: sivevsky
item.description:
Early morning on the second tour day: good breakfast ,bike bags assembly and road hit!Before me was day full of wonderful tourist places which we on the Balkans know very well.The road was most up and down along the coast. I was aiming to reach Ulicnj by the end of the day ,find a nudists …

Day2: Budva-Skadar Read More »
item.content:encoded:
Early morning on the second tour day: good breakfast ,bike bags assembly and road hit!
Before me was day full of wonderful tourist places which we on the Balkans know very well.
The road was most up and down along the coast. I was aiming to reach Ulicnj by the end of the day ,find a nudists beach and spend the night there. Some of the tourist places that i crossed are: Sveti Stefan, Petrovac na Moru,Sutomore and Bar. In the last one i met a German cyclist, Markus with whom i spent a few days cycling in Albania. On the way to the Albanian border i continued my way to Ulcinj hoping to see Markus next day in Skadar. It  turned out however that the way to Ulcinj was quite long and i couldn’t make it until dark. Because of some stereotypes, we in Macedonia are somehow afraid of Albania and Albanians, not to mention riding there at night. That’s why i changed my mind and turned back  the bike in direction Skadar where i would meet Markus who already found a double bed room in a nice small hotel.
Skadar is a city  on the Skadar Lake and its style and architecture are very similar to my home place.

I expected cheap meals and wonderful food but same as everywhere i have been: no cheap food was found at least for Macedonian standard. After a brief walk in the city with Markus, we got back to the hotel and had a nice rest.
The morning was sunny and when i went in the breakfast yard ,Markus was already there consuming his first coffee. The breakfast was amazing, full of different kinds of food and small delights. It is  a pity i don’t remember the name of this hotel otherwise i would recommend it to anyone going to Skadar. Another 100 km were in front of us on the way to Tirana.

item.title: Day1: Dubrovnik-Budva
item.dc:creator: sivevsky
item.description:
First day of the first biking tour !No experience ,just adrenalin and i must admit, small fear.I have heard that the coastal road is very busy  and can be dangerous for cyclists.It was six o’clock in the morning when  i left the bus station. After half an hour wandering in the city trying to find …

Day1: Dubrovnik-Budva Read More »
item.content:encoded:
First day of the first biking tour !No experience ,just adrenalin and i must admit, small fear.
I have heard that the coastal road is very busy  and can be dangerous for cyclists.
It was six o’clock in the morning when  i left the bus station. After half an hour wandering in the city trying to find my way, i found the coastal road and headed down to my first stop: Herceg Novi which  was in around 50 km and includes  border crossing to Montenegro.
The ride was enjoyable since it was early morning on Sunday and the road was empty. I had no difficulties to arrive in Herceg Novi and find a place for a good breakfast and coffee. My usual routine would be to avoid heavy eating in the middle of a ride, but this was  an exception since my lack of experience. The road took me along the  bay of Kotor which is considered one of the best cycling roads in Europe as a result of its panoramic views. I decided to fully encircle it instead of taking the ferry. In this way i could see the city of Kotor.

Kotor is  an amazing place.In fact, the water brings magic everywhere. I wonder how my life would have been if i was born there?
After a lunch break in a not so cheap restaurant(every restaurant seemed expensive in Kotor), i got back on the road aiming to make no more breaks until final destination.
The final part of the trip that day was exhausting because of the noon heat ,increased traffic and a few   short tunnels which scared me to death. Just before Budva there is a steep 2-3 km hill but once you are up ,the whole city is in front of you. The next step is of course finding a sleeping place: the biggest and most important decision  in  a cyclist life.
I have targeted a few camping sites during my preparations  for the trip and now when i was on the place and checked a few of them. I decided for a camp in Becici which was not far from the city beach. I rented a camping van for 8 euros which was comfortable enough(with exception of the ants).
The camp had a small locking room at the side as well a kitchen with utensils. What more do you want in  a bikers life? Ah  yes, a can of  beer by the sea!
